Author: B. R. Ferrer; W. M. Mohammed; J. L. Martinez Lastra
Title: A solution for processing supply chain events within ontology-based descriptions
Publication Title: IECON 2016 - 42nd Annual Conference of the IEEE Industrial Electronics Society
Abstract Note: The industry is constantly moving towards the research, implementation and deployment of new solutions that permit the optimization of processes. Nowadays, such solutions consist mostly on ICT developments, which permit the collection, distribution, integration, analysis, and manipulation of heterogeneous data. The under way Cloud Collaborative Manufacturing Networks (C2NET) project targets the development of cloud-enabled tools for supporting the SMEs supply network optimization of manufacturing and logistic assets. The C2NET solution includes the implementation of paradigms as e.g. cloud computing or service-oriented and event-driven architectures, used for wide data integration. Among its requirements, the C2NET platform needs a solution for catch, process and react to events triggered in different locations of collaborative manufacturing networks, which are endowed with devices that permits the integration of Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS). This paper presents the architecture and main functionality of a knowledge-based approach that allows processing supply chain events handled by CPS devices. The main component of the presented solution is the SECA ontology, which is a knowledge base that can be updated at runtime. The main purpose of the ontology is to describe events, their status and the actions to be performed once a set of events are triggered in certain order. This research work offers a solution that can be employed by the C2NET platform not only to catch and process events; but also to notify linked data consumers.

Author: J. Kohler; T. Specht; K. Simov
Title: An approach for a security and privacy-aware cloud-based storage of data in the Semantic Web
Publication Title: 2016 First IEEE International Conference on Computer Communication and the Internet (ICCCI)
Abstract Note: This work proposes to include security and privacy into to context of Linked Open Data (LOD) and the Semantic Web. Here, a database partitioning approach to logically and physically separate data and distribute the partitions across several different cloud providers is applied. This data distribution is called fixed vertical partitioning and distribution approach (FVPD), as data schemes are vertically partitioned and distributed across various different cloud providers. Hence, this framework uses a security-by-distribution approach to storing sensitive data securely and privacy-ware in all possible cloud deployment models and thus, it provides a solution to improve the level of security and privacy. The proposed FVPD approach also becomes viable in the context of LOD and the Semantic Web. Furthermore, in relevant literature no approach in this context has been dealing with security and privacy so far. Therefore, this work transfers the FVPD approach from relational databases to Semantic Web Frameworks (Apache Jena, Sesame, etc.) that provide storage engines for RDF data and corresponding SPARQL endpoints. Above that, the query performance of such a federated environment is compared to a non-partitioned and non-distributed environment. For this, an adapted version of the TPC-W benchmark is used. Thus, this work shows how the query performance is affected when relational database data are exposed as SPARQL endpoints in RDF-based form and how the FVPD approach influences the query performance. Finally, it illustrates a mechanism to improve the level of security and privacy through a security-by-distribution approach.
Extra: Journal Abbreviation: 2016 First IEEE International Conference on Computer Communication and the Internet (ICCCI)
Manual Tags: cloud computing; semantic web; Security; Data privacy; Context; Resource description framework; security; RDF-based data; Distributed databases; Relational databases
Conference Name: 2016 First IEEE International Conference on Computer Communication and the Internet (ICCCI)

Author: F. Devin; A. Jourdan; D. Laffly; Y. Le Nir
Title: Cloud data architecture applied to urban management
Publication Title: 2016 Eighth International Conference on Knowledge and Systems Engineering (KSE)
Abstract Note: Open Data now provides access to updated data dedicated to urban development. The traditional approach of using production data for decision on land management needs to be rethought in the light of these new opportunities and should therefore addressed towards dynamic management of geographic information. Institutional sites such as INSEE semantically annotate their data facilitating the discovery of contextual data. Linked Open Data cloud network offers semantic access to a huge amount of thematic data including an important geographic subset. These new opportunities always generate a greater amount of usable data. Big Data tools, like Spark, make it easy to handle this amount unbounded data via conventional data-mining algorithms. We group all these issues under the generic name of Cloud Data that has sense only if it is integrated perfectly into a cloud computing environment for efficient processing and reactive application (SaaS application, Restfull services, D3JS library, …). We offer an example of a dedicated application for the Pau urban community in which all Cloud Data is integrated as a SaaS (Software as a Service).

Author: A. M. Alkalbani; F. K. Hussain
Title: A comparative study and future research directions in cloud service discovery
Publication Title: 2016 IEEE 11th Conference on Industrial Electronics and Applications (ICIEA)
Abstract Note: Cloud computing technology is a new paradigm which provides Information Technology (IT) resources via the Internet. This new shift in the way that IT re-sources are offered to the user brings new challenges, such as cloud service discovery. Nowadays, cloud users are faced with a dilemma as they have an abundant choice of cloud services. Moreover, many cloud providers offer a range of services which deliver similar functionality. Locating the best and most appropriate cloud service with a suitable and capable provider is a primary concern for any consumer. In order to clearly comprehend the scope of this problem, a thorough analysis of the limitations of cloud service discovery approaches is required which, in turn, will empower researchers to deliver better solutions for consumers to make an informed decision and choose the right service. This paper presents an overview of the current cloud service discovery trends and challenges in recent studies. Additionally, the reviewed approaches are classified according to service discovery architecture and techniques. Furthermore, these approaches are compared and analysed from several perspectives including approach model/architecture, service type, ontology representation (domain, language, and reasoning), dynamic discovery model, evaluation model, user's preferences techniques, data updates, and public repositories.

Author: T. Uchibayashi; B. O. Apduhan; N. Shiratori
Title: An Ontology-Based Framework for Hybrid Cloud Resiliency Mechanism
Publication Title: 2016 IEEE 14th Intl Conf on Dependable, Autonomic and Secure Computing, 14th Intl Conf on Pervasive Intelligence and Computing, 2nd Intl Conf on Big Data Intelligence and Computing and Cyber Science and Technology Congress(DASC/PiCom/DataCom/CyberSciTech)
Abstract Note: Hybrid cloud computing paradigm is gaining wide acceptance to multi-faceted IT organizations to meet the users' different sets of requirements for different types of applications. However, this can also create an array of issues, such as complex architectures, security, service provisioning in cases of resources failures/disaster, etc. To mitigate the impact and minimize trade-offs, we proposed an ontology-based framework to provide support for a resiliency mechanism in the hybrid cloud. We adopted ontology technology to provide a unified representations of cloud service names to facilitate the discovery and selection of the best-match cloud service in cases of failures. As types of cloud services evolve over time, we adopted ontology clustering to speed up the search process. Preliminary experiment results provided promising results.

Author: A. Alfazi; Q. Z. Sheng; W. E. Zhang; L. Yao; T. H. Noor
Title: Identification as a Service: Large-Scale Cloud Service Discovery over the World Wide Web
Publication Title: 2016 IEEE International Congress on Big Data (BigData Congress)
Abstract Note: Cloud computing is provisioned with high flexibility with regard to on demand infrastructures, platforms and software as services through the Internet. The unique characteristics of cloud services such as dynamic and diverse services offering at different levels, as well as the lack of standardized description, are becoming important challenges in efficiently discovering cloud services for customers. In this paper, we propose a cloud service search engine that has the capability to automatically identify cloud services aiming at improving the accuracy when searching cloud services in real environments. Our search engine can detect cloud services effectively from the Web sources. Furthermore, we focus on learning the cloud service features, such as similarity function, semantic ontology and cloud service components to identify the cloud services. We use a real cloud service dataset to build an identifier. Our cloud service identifier can be used to automatically determine whether a given Web source is a cloud service with high accuracy.

Author: Ke Xu; Hongming Cai
Title: Data resource semantic support method research based on meta-data annotation
Publication Title: 2016 World Automation Congress (WAC)
Abstract Note: The concept of the cloud is no longer limited to providing remote hardware or platform support with the development of cloud computing technology. Instead, it encapsulates all aspects of the content in computer field into service invoked by others. As an important part of software, data resource has become core services to the cloud platform in areas such as collaborative manufacturing and collaborative service. Since these data are complex in structure, strongly independent but related to each other, it is necessary to annotate these data to improve their operability and make them able to be utilized more widely. This paper wants to design an annotation method based on word segmentation and semantics replacement aimed at metadata according to the characteristics of the meta-data itself. As a result, these data resource can then be understood by computers and further support later studies such as data fusion and semantic retrieval.

Author: Q. -z. Niu; Y. -d. Zheng
Title: Optimization of RDF reasoning based on MapReduce
Publication Title: 2016 World Automation Congress (WAC)
Abstract Note: With the development of information technology, the resource description framework (RDF) occupies very important position in structure of the semantic web. An effective way to enhance the efficiency of the RDF data query is RDF closures. Our work is improve the RDF reasoning in MapReduce framework. The algorithm is based on packet classification efficiency of a few of candidate rules, as well as the NoSQL data storage avoiding repetition, corresponding to the RDF properties and concepts. The optimization algorithm of MapReduce is given a new closure generation process. Our approach use RDFS inference rules and the RDF triples in relationship between Map and Reduce operations and generate the RDF closures, improve the generate efficiency of closure. Based on RDF MapReduce algorithm for RDF closure, look forward more suitable RDF closure computing scheme on cloud computing environment.

Author: H. Chen; G. Tian; F. Lu; G. Liu
Title: A hybrid cloud robot framework based on intelligent space
Publication Title: 2016 12th World Congress on Intelligent Control and Automation (WCICA)
Abstract Note: Cloud computing has become an increasingly popular topic in recent years. It has provided alternatives for designing and implementing robot or intelligent space platform. Compared with traditional approaches where users purchase a robot and manage its own hardware or software on an ongoing basis. While researchers wish to transform their computing resources infrastructure into cloud, whether as virtual computing resources in a private cloud, virtual computing resources in a public cloud, physical computing resources, or as a combination of all these different resources in a hybrid cloud infrastructure. In this paper, a hybrid cloud robot framework is presented. An open source software named Apache CloudStack designed to deploy and manage large networks of virtual machines, as a highly available, highly scalable Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) cloud computing platform. We also proposed a knowledge representation method for service robots, where knowledge is represented hierarchically and described in ontology web language.

Author: T. W. Sitanggang; K. Kamar; H. Priyono; A. W. A. Rahman; H. Nusantoro; M. Sunengsih
Title: Enhancing Educational Data Integrity Using Blockchain and Ontologies
Publication Title: 2025 4th International Conference on Creative Communication and Innovative Technology (ICCIT)
Abstract Note: The growing need for secure and transparent data management in educational institutions has brought attention to Blockchain technology. This study explores the implementation of Blockchain for educational data integrity, focusing on how decentralized ledger technologies (DLTs) and Merkle root methods enhance trust, transparency, and security in academic environments. By integrating an ontology-based framework, this research provides a structured approach to organizing and verifying digital credentials, student records, and institutional data. The ontology aids in reducing conceptual ambiguity and supports interoperability among diverse educational technologies. Through technical analysis of Blockchain components, such as Merkle trees, cryptographic hashes, and block structures, the study demonstrates how Blockchain ensures tamper-proof and verifiable data transactions. Case studies from universities applying Blockchain-Based certification further highlight the feasibility and challenges of adoption, including infrastructure readiness, stakeholder resistance, and integration with legacy systems. The findings suggest that combining Blockchain with emerging technologies like AI and cloud computing can establish a resilient, scalable, and secure educational ecosystem. This paper contributes a theoretical and practical perspective for institutions aiming to modernize academic record keeping while addressing privacy, authenticity, and long-term data sustainability.

Author: P. C. Jakku; S. Chippagiri; N. R. Uppalapati; U. Dasi
Title: Multi-Cloud Semantic Orchestration of AI-Driven Pipelines for Privacy-First LLM Inference
Publication Title: 2025 International Conference on Computing Technologies & Data Communication (ICCTDC)
Abstract Note: Because more people need scalable and private Large Language Model (LLM) processing in the cloud, better orchestration methods for using different cloud resources are required. This research proposes a new architecture for handling Multi-Cloud Semantic Orchestration of AI-driven data pipelines to make LLM inference workflows more efficient, secure and in line with company policies. The framework makes it possible to effectively assign tasks and control data with the help of ontology-based knowledge graphs and added metadata by semantic enrichment. Our system uses distributed coordination engines, ensures both differential privacy and secure multiparty computation and selects appropriate models for proper latency, throughput and compliance. Experimental findings from using well-known NLP datasets show that the orchestration strategy proposed here reduces latency by up to 38 % and ensures more privacy by 22 % than standard single-cloud systems. This research supports better LLM operations (LLMOps) in areas like healthcare and finance, since both need to pay close attention to data protection and privacy laws.

Author: S. T. Yalla; I. Batra; A. Malik
Title: Security Ontologies in Cloud Computing
Publication Title: 2025 6th International Conference for Emerging Technology (INCET)
Abstract Note: Cloud computing (CC) has the potential to augment collaboration, scalability, and accessibility, while providing cost-saving opportunities via enhanced and efficient computing, thus enabling enterprises to maintain focus. Cloud-based security ontologies are organized frameworks that delineate and classify topics pertinent to security in CC settings. They assist in standardizing language and enhance communication, interoperability, and comprehension among diverse stakeholders, including security experts, developers, and organizations. The ontology-based security strategy is one of the security solutions used by relevant parties. Nevertheless, target customers and cloud service providers see it as complex and lacking in security, since the applicable paradigms for various contexts are not clearly defined. Previous research has identified many security ideas that service providers might use, employing several evaluation methodologies. This highlights the growing need for reviewing the literature on Cloud Security Ontology (CSO). This research outlines the current state of the art in cloud computing ontology (CCO) and conducts a comprehensive literature review on the topic. Using the systematic literature review (SLR) approach, we identified 100 papers; 60 were selected based on established criteria, and 25 were assessed to be pertinent to the study. Scholars have shown active interest in four main areas of CC—service description, cloud security (CS), cloud resource management, cloud interoperability, and cloud service discovery—where cloud ontologies have had a significant impact. According to the research, fifteen of the thirty-one methods described in the literature for using ontologies in the cloud domain are still in use in legacy computing settings. The findings reveal several issues with improving company operations in cloud and multi-cloud settings via the use of ontologies. This paper delineates unsolved difficulties and potential future paths for academics in cloud ontology.

Author: X. Xie; J. Liu; B. Cao; W. Zhao; S. Lin; M. Shi; J. Chen
Title: DiffMSR: A Multi-Semantic Graph Diffusion Model for Service Recommendation
Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Services Computing
Abstract Note: With the rapid development of cloud computing and service computing, service recommendation systems play a crucial role in helping users efficiently filter the appropriate services. However, the sparsity of service data and the presence of noise in interactions make it extremely challenging to accurately capture user preferences. Existing service recommendation methods based on Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) primarily rely on ID aggregation, often neglecting the richness of textual semantics and are susceptible to interaction noise, resulting in suboptimal modeling of user-service relationships. Although Large Language Models (LLMs) demonstrate remarkable advantages in capturing textual semantics, current methods struggle to effectively align structural representations with textual representations, limiting improvements in recommendation performance. To address these challenges, we propose an innovative multi-semantic graph diffusion model for service recommendation, DiffMSR, which aims to align textual and structural representations while learning the generation process of interaction graphs in a denoising manner. This approach mitigates data sparsity and effectively reduces noise interference. Specifically, the model leverages LLMs to capture the textual semantic features of service descriptions and integrates them with structured semantic information from knowledge graphs. Through cross-semantic contrastive learning, it achieves heterogeneous semantic alignment. Furthermore, the model introduces a multisemantic diffusion-based generation framework, which iteratively denoises to construct high-quality user-service interaction graphs. This significantly enhances the multi-semantic awareness of user representations, thereby improving recommendation performance. Experiments on public service datasets demonstrate that DiffMSR outperforms existing state-of-the-art baseline methods, achieving improvements of 4.13% and 6.37% in recommendation accuracy and recall, respectively.
Manual Tags: Knowledge graphs; Semantics; Recommender systems; service recommendation; LLM; knowledge graph; Feature extraction; Data models; Accuracy; Noise reduction; Large language models; Contrastive learning; Noise; graph diffusion; semantic alignment

Author: A. K. J; R. S. Amshavalli; V. R. D; V. S. V. Varma; G. Kavitha
Title: A Semantic Driven Framework for Energy Efficient Task Scheduling in Dynamic Cloud Environment
Publication Title: 2025 4th International Conference on Sentiment Analysis and Deep Learning (ICSADL)
Abstract Note: The rapid expansion of cloud computing has led to increased energy consumption, raising concerns about its environmental impact. Despite advancements in scheduling algorithms, existing methods face critical challenges, including suboptimal energy efficiency, limited adaptability to dynamic cloud environments, and insufficient context-aware decision-making. Recent techniques, such as Meta Reinforcement Learning, Genetic Algorithms, and Energy-Aware Scheduling, show potential but often struggle with high computational complexity, static resource allocation, or scalability issues. These shortcomings result in inefficient resource utilization, elevated energy usage, and difficulties in meeting Service Level Agreement (SLA) requirements. To address these challenges, this study introduces the Energy Efficient Semantic Scheduling Framework (ESSF), a novel approach combining semantic reasoning and energy profiling to optimize task scheduling in dynamic cloud environments. The framework integrates three key components: (1) Dynamic Energy Profiling (DEP) for real-time energy monitoring, (2) Semantic Resource Matching (SRM) utilizing knowledge graphs for context-aware allocation, and (3) Adaptive Workload Balancing (AWB) to dynamically redistribute tasks for improved resource utilization and energy efficiency. Experiments using the Google Cluster Trace Dataset demonstrate that ESSF reduces energy consumption by up to 25% compared to traditional methods while achieving 90% resource utilization and 97% SLA compliance. These results highlight the potential of the proposed framework to overcome existing limitations, offering a scalable, adaptive, and environmentally sustainable solution for task scheduling in cloud computing.

Conference Name: 2025 4th International Conference on Sentiment Analysis and Deep Learning (ICSADL)

Author: X. Xie; J. Liu; B. Cao; Q. Peng; S. Liu; G. Kang
Title: Service Recommendation Based on Multi-Level View Contrastive Learning
Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
Abstract Note: In the context of the rapid development of service-oriented computing and cloud computing, selecting the service that meets the user’s needs from an ever-increasing number of Web services is always challenging. Exploiting auxiliary information such as a Knowledge Graph (KG) can significantly improve the effectiveness of service recommendations. However, current KG-based service recommendation methods usually merely integrate the knowledge semantic information into the user-service interaction model, which ignores the importance of global structure and does not fully consider the in-depth learning of individual user preferences. To this end, this paper proposes a Multi-Level View Contrastive Learning for Service Recommendation (MCSR) approach to address the above challenges. In particular, unlike traditional approaches that consider only two views, we consider three views, i.e., the global structure view, the local collaboration view, and the semantic view. Specifically, the user-service graph is regarded as the collaboration view, the service-entity graph as the semantic view, and the user-service-entity graph as the structural view. By applying contrastive learning across these views at different levels, MCSR fully leverages graph features and structural information, integrating auxiliary relational semantics into user-service interaction modeling. Furthermore, recognizing that the influence of auxiliary information on interactions varies between users and services, a meta-network strategy enables adaptive, personalized knowledge transfer across views, significantly improving recommendation accuracy., since the influence of auxiliary information on interactions varies between users and services, a meta-network strategy enables adaptive, personalized knowledge transfer across views, significantly enhancing recommendation accuracy. The experimental results show that MCSR significantly outperforms current state-of-the-art methods, with the positive impact of its key components on the recommended performance verified by ablation experiments.
Journal Abbreviation: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
Manual Tags: Knowledge graphs; Semantics; Knowledge transfer; contrastive learning; meta-networks; Multi-level view; service recommendation; Quality of service; Collaborative filtering; Mashups; Social networking (online); Collaboration; Predictive models; Accuracy

Author: W. Zhu; S. Huang; S. Lu
Title: Design of Digital Integrated Intelligent Platform for Electric Power Design Based on Knowledge Graph
Publication Title: 2024 6th International Academic Exchange Conference on Science and Technology Innovation (IAECST)
Abstract Note: With the rapid development of the power industry, traditional power design methods can no longer meet the increasingly complex demands of modern power systems. This paper proposes a digital integrated intelligent platform for power design based on knowledge graphs, aimed at enhancing the efficiency and quality of power design. By integrating big data processing, artificial intelligence, blockchain, and cloud computing technologies, the platform achieves automation of design processes, standardized data management, and intelligent decision support. The multi-layer architecture of the platform supports the full lifecycle management of power design projects and significantly improves the efficiency of data processing and collaborative work. Experimental results indicate that the platform demonstrates significant advantages in enhancing design accuracy, reducing human error, and improving work efficiency, thereby facilitating the digital and intelligent transformation of power design.

Author: S. Kouchi; H. Nacer; H. Slimani
Title: Multi-criteria based virtual SaaS Selection in Cloud Environment
Publication Title: Global Congress on Emerging Technologies (GCET-2024)
Abstract Note: The process of selecting Software as a Service (SaaS) in Cloud Computing depends on providers’ capabilities to articulate the non-functional attributes of their SaaS offerings semantically and understand customer requests along with their non-functional requirements. This study conceptualizes SaaS selection as a multi-criteria combinatorial problem within predefined constraints. To address this, we introduce a hybrid approach incorporating an entire optimization algorithm. Our method leverages semantic and microservice (individual) SaaS descriptions in the Ontology Web Language for Services (OWL-S). Each micro SaaS is linked to compatible SaaS instances (offering similar functionality) in a unified environment, guided by the compatibility concept. A micro-SaaS may not satisfy a particular functional need in specific contexts. However, it is possible to meet customer requirements by combining the available SaaS instances, called virtual SaaS. The chosen SaaS should be the best based on the defined quality and quantitative criteria. Our proposed approach, employing multi-criteria analysis, capitalizes on a dedicated Quality of Service (QoS) ontology tailored for the cloud environment and web applications. Moreover, a simulation design proved that a substantial selection of SaaS(s) could be achieved in a cloud.

Conference Name: Global Congress on Emerging Technologies (GCET-2024)

Author: W. Wong; Z. Alomari; Y. Shao; M. I. Satti
Title: Knowledge Graph to Facilitate Cloud Security Compliance with NIST Cybersecurity Framework
Publication Title: 2024 2nd International Conference on Computer, Vision and Intelligent Technology (ICCVIT)
Abstract Note: Cybersecurity compliance has become increasingly complex due to evolving threats, overlapping standards, and rapidly changing requirements driven by emerging technologies like artificial intelligence. Organizations face significant challenges in efficiently mapping compliance requirements to specific security controls. This paper addresses this issue within the cloud industry by presenting a systematic approach to deploying a knowledge graph or ontology that maps cloud security controls at the granular implementation level to the NIST Cybersecurity Framework. Unlike previous efforts focused on high-level mappings, this approach enhances compliance efficiency and supports integration with common software languages such as HTTP and Java. The proposed methodology can also be adapted to other compliance standards.

Author: R. R. Cecil; J. L. Miranda; M. Nagy; M. Da Silveira; M. Zanin
Title: Advanced Methodologies and Technologies for Innovative Information Systems
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedicine (BIBM)
Abstract Note: Nowadays, Information Systems (IS) in healthcare systems are being successively updated, either incorporating advanced Optimization tools combined with Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Large Language Models (LLM), or using innovative computing features for storage, processing, security, privacy, and friendly interface. Large efforts are required to design, validate and implement such developments, diverse communities in multiple scientific domains are involved, and new approaches are key to cope with the transdisciplinary gaps. In this paper we outline and discuss the relevant technologies and methodologies for IS within the context of health emergencies. Advanced and innovative approaches are being applied within the Health Informatics area, and we address a set of key technologies (e.g., Cloud Computing, AI-based platforms, Neural Networks) and methodologies (e.g., Knowledge Graphs, advanced Optimization, Multi-Criteria Decision Making) that are being relevant within the Health Emergency Responses (HER) framework, and also for the health informatics communities.

Author: S. Moreschini; M. Albano; D. Hastbacka
Title: Best Practices for Resource Provisioning Declaration Within the Cognitive Cloud Continuum
Publication Title: 2024 50th Euromicro Conference on Software Engineering and Advanced Applications (SEAA)
Abstract Note: The evolution of cloud computing, driven by ad-vances in mobile, edge technologies, and AI, has led to the development of the Cognitive Cloud Continuum (COCLCON). However, this paradigm introduces new challenges in managing and optimizing computing resources across a heterogeneous environment. This paper explores best practices for declaring resources within COCLCON, with a focus on efficient resource allocation and transparently declaring available resources by de-vices. In this study, we undertook a non-holistic literature review to identify current technologies used to specify requirements and to determine current gaps in best practices. The main outcome of our work is a proposed schema for Resource Provisioning Declaration, which will allow for increased knowledge related to the available devices and resources within the COCLCON.

Author: L. Qinyi
Title: Research on Data-Driven Financial Risk Prediction Model Based on Cloud Computing
Publication Title: 2024 International Conference on Computers, Information Processing and Advanced Education (CIPAE)
Abstract Note: This article aims to explore a data-driven financial risk prediction model based on cloud computing technology. This model achieves accurate identification and prediction of corporate financial risks by integrating advanced algorithms and knowledge graph technology. This article proposes a new risk prediction algorithm model that combines multiple methods such as machine learning, deep learning, and statistical analysis to learn patterns from historical data and predict future financial risks. In addition, the application of knowledge graph enables the model to better understand the internal connections of financial data and improve the accuracy of predictions. Finally, through system simulation experiments, this paper verifies the effectiveness and stability of the proposed model in practical applications. Experimental results show that this model can significantly improve the accuracy of financial risk prediction and provide powerful decision support for enterprises. This research not only enriches the theoretical system in the field of financial risk management, but also provides new ideas and technical means for the practice of financial risk management and control of enterprises.

Author: Z. Chen; Y. Zhao; F. Teng; J. Hu; B. Tian; H. Zhang
Title: Dynamic Searchable Symmetric Encrypted Knowledge Graph
Publication Title: 2024 16th International Conference on Communication Software and Networks (ICCSN)
Abstract Note: With the rapid development of knowledge graphs and cloud computing, most people choose to store knowledge graphs on commercial cloud platforms. However, since cloud platforms are not completely trustworthy, this exposes graph data to security risks. Therefore, protecting knowledge graph data stored on third-party cloud platforms is essential. Based on these considerations, we propose a Dynamic Searchable Symmetric Encryption-based Knowledge Graph scheme (DSSE-KG). DSSE-KG aims to address the privacy and security risks associated with storing knowledge graph data on cloud servers. Compared to existing schemes, DSSE-KG not only ensures the data security of knowledge graphs but also provides multi-hop relationship retrieval and dynamic update capabilities. Performance tests on multiple publicly available real-world datasets demonstrate that the DSSE-KG scheme achieves a good balance between security, functionality, and efficiency for knowledge graphs.

Author: X. Xie; J. Zhang
Title: Link Prediction in Knowledge Graphs for Graph Convolutional Networks
Publication Title: 2024 International Conference on Intelligent Algorithms for Computational Intelligence Systems (IACIS)
Abstract Note: In the cloud computing environment, the application of data encryption technology is of great significance to the improvement of network information security. This paper discusses the key challenges and solutions of data encryption technology in cloud computing, focusing on the application of symmetric and asymmetric encryption technologies and their effects. Comparative experimental analyses show that symmetric encryption has a processing speed of about 10,000 encryption operations per second and low resource consumption, while asymmetric encryption has a processing speed of about 500 encryption operations per second but excels in security and key management. The experimental results show that the combined use of symmetric and asymmetric encryption can achieve more efficient and secure data protection in cloud computing environments. Ultimately, this paper suggests future research directions to further enhance data security in cloud computing environments.

Author: H. Sun; L. Gu; C. Dong; X. Ma; Z. Liu; Z. Li
Title: Cloud Computing Resource Scheduling Algorithm Based on Unsampled Collaborative Knowledge Graph Network
Publication Title: IEEE Access
Abstract Note: A cloud computing resource scheduling algorithm based on sampled collaborative knowledge graph network is designed to address the issues of lag in the process of cloud computing resource scheduling, high overall load rate, and large transient amplitude and phase errors. Based on graph convolutional neural networks, analyze the target load of cloud platforms, construct multi hop data transmission paths one by one, and perform deep level information load balancing; Establish a multiplexing information transmission model, correct the initial weights of graph convolutional neural networks, combine reverse transmission calculation methods, integrate and balance cloud computing resources, and confirm the optimal resource scheduling plan; Integrating class convolution and human-machine interaction attention mechanism, the value of the previous time series neural unit is transferred to the current neural unit, and the classification output sequence of knowledge graph relational data feature fragments is analyzed. The knowledge graph data fragments are processed based on class convolution and human-machine interaction attention mechanism, and different sizes of linear aggregators are used to capture deep level information, completing the design of cloud computing resource scheduling algorithm. The experimental results show that although the load rate is on the rise, the highest is only 89%, and the scheduling rate is relatively high, ranging from 38.9 to 43.1bps; The energy consumption is relatively low, not exceeding 40.106mW. In terms of transient amplitude and phase, the proposed method can control the error within 2.0. Ensure the efficiency and practical application effectiveness of cloud computing resource scheduling algorithms.
Manual Tags: Cloud computing; Knowledge graph; Knowledge graphs; cloud computing; Resource management; Convolutional neural networks; graph convolutional neural network; resource scheduling; Scheduling algorithms; Graph convolutional networks; Load modeling; Multiplexing; Relays; Transient analysis

Author: P. D; P. Mehta; D. Sood
Title: Automated Semantic Interpretations in Web Applications via Cloud Computing Aspects
Publication Title: 2024 International Conference on Communication, Computer Sciences and Engineering (IC3SE)
Abstract Note: The creation and execution of applications in several disciplines have been greatly aided by the integration of cloud computing and semantic web technologies. Although they are independent entities, they may also be combined in many ways to provide answers—a subject that has been thoroughly researched lately. The number of “new cloud providers, applications, facilities, management systems, and data” has significantly increased in recent years. The complexity that has resulted from this expansion emphasises the need for new technology in order to efficiently manage and support these varied and many services and resources. As a result, difficulties with “cloud services and resources” transferability, compatibility, security, choice, negotiation, identity, and specification might arise. Semantic Technologies are a vital tool for reassessing these issues because of their enormous “cloud computing” capacity. This study uses a variety of sources to examine and evaluate the impact of “Semantic-Web Technology” in the cloud. Moreover, a cloud-based engagement strategy shows how we may leverage the features and advantages of cloud computing to build the semantic web and provide automatic semantic annotations to online applications on a large scale.

Author: P. Li; Q. Du; S. Zhao; P. Fang
Title: Advancing Root Cause Analysis in Cloud-native System with Knowledge Graph Path Embedding Translation
Publication Title: 2024 27th International Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work in Design (CSCWD)
Abstract Note: Cloud computing technologies, including cloud-native and containerization, have gained prominence in recent years, attributed to their exceptional scalability, enhanced resource utilization, and expedited deployment capabilities. However, their inherent complexity and the intricate interplay of internal components heighten the risk of sporadic and unforeseen anomalies. To address these challenges, Root Cause Analysis (RCA) is employed to accurately identify problematic services (pods) and mine the precise faults behind observed anomalies. Tailored to the limitations of conventional RCA algorithms, we propose a novel approach that jointly models operation entities and their relationships as learnable embeddings. Additionally, this method integrates fault propagation information to further improve RCA accuracy. Our evaluation involves developing a prototype within the Kubernetes cloud-native system. Extensive experimental results validate the efficacy of our approach.

Author: P. Srinivas; F. Husain; A. Parayil; A. Choure; C. Bansal; S. Rajmohan
Title: Intelligent Monitoring Framework for Cloud Services: A Data-Driven Approach
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE/ACM 46th International Conference on Software Engineering: Software Engineering in Practice (ICSE-SEIP)
Abstract Note: Cloud service owners need to continuously monitor their services to ensure high availability and reliability. Gaps in monitoring can lead to delay in incident detection and significant negative customer impact. Current process of monitor creation is ad-hoc and reactive in nature. Developers create monitors using their tribal knowledge and, primarily, a trial and error based process. As a result, monitors often have incomplete coverage which leads to production issues, or, redundancy which results in noise and wasted effort. In this work, we address this issue by proposing an intelli-gent monitoring framework that recommends monitors for cloud services based on their service properties. We start by mining the attributes of 30,000+ monitors from 791 production services at Microsoft and derive a structured ontology for monitors. We focus on two crucial dimensions: what to monitor (resources) and which metrics to monitor. We conduct an extensive empirical study and derive key insights on the major classes of monitors employed by cloud services at Microsoft, their associated dimensions, and the interrelationship between service properties and this ontology. Using these insights, we propose a deep learning based framework that recommends monitors based on the service properties. Finally, we conduct a user study with engineers from Microsoft which demonstrates the usefulness of the proposed framework. The proposed framework along with the ontology driven projections, succeeded in creating production quality rec-ommendations for majority of resource classes. This was also validated by the users from the study who rated the framework's usefulness as 4.27 out of 5.

Author: G. S. Bisht; N. Gobi; V. M. Kapse
Title: A Deep Analysis on Security Aspects of Cloud Computing Ontologies
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE International Conference on Computing, Power and Communication Technologies (IC2PCT)
Abstract Note: The primary objective of this research is to get a comprehensive understanding of Cloud Computing ontologies, their applications, and their specific areas of interest. The proposed research methodology for this systematic review comprises a well-defined research topic, criteria for including and excluding studies, and a comprehensive search strategy to identify relevant source papers for the review. The chosen research is categorized into four main areas: elucidation of cloud resources and services, elaboration of cloud security, clarity of cloud interoperability, and understanding of cloud services discovery and selection. Utilizing ontologies to improve the security and smooth integration of cloud computing services uncovers various challenges and identifies areas for more research.

Author: Z. Li; L. Chen; Z. Feng; H. Wang; J. Shi; X. Cai
Title: Evaluation of Cloud Platform Operation and Maintenance Time Series Knowledge Graph State by Integrating Knowledge Graph and Graph Learning
Publication Title: 2023 5th International Academic Exchange Conference on Science and Technology Innovation (IAECST)
Abstract Note: Cloud computing platforms have become an important infrastructure for modern enterprises to build business architectures, but with the continuous expansion of cloud platform scale, the difficulty of operation and maintenance has also increased exponentially. In order to better manage operation and maintenance data and improve operation and maintenance efficiency, this paper proposes a cloud platform operation and maintenance temporal knowledge graph state evaluation that integrates knowledge graph and graph learning. Based on the knowledge graph theory, a cloud platform operation and maintenance knowledge graph is constructed based on Sentence BERT, and the general static knowledge graph is extended to temporal knowledge graph, A graph convolutional neural network based reasoning method for cloud platform operation and maintenance temporal knowledge graph has been proposed. Through the above methods, the cloud platform operation and maintenance system can effectively capture the changes in temporal data and node feature information, improving the efficiency and quality of cloud platform operation and maintenance.

Author: Q. Wu; Y. Wang
Title: Research on Intelligent Question-Answering Systems Based on Large Language Models and Knowledge Graphs
Publication Title: 2023 16th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Design (ISCID)
Abstract Note: With the continuous development of artificial intelligence and cloud computing technologies, the emergence of large language models (LLMs) has created new opportunities for intelligent applications. However, large language models may lack authenticity and accuracy when providing answers in specific professional domains, and they even generate "illusory facts." In response to the limitations of current large language models in solving specific professional fields, this paper proposes to use large language models and knowledge graph technology to construct an intelligent question answering system for specific fields. Through systematic training and optimization, efficient domain specific knowledge Q&A has been achieved, improving the satisfaction rate of domain specific knowledge Q&A. The intelligent question answering system based on large models and knowledge graphs brings more convenience to people's lives and work, which is beneficial for users to obtain intelligent solutions in fields such as education, healthcare, and customer service.

Author: M. Yang; K. Zhang; C. Mu; X. Wang; Y. Liu; H. Zhang
Title: A Shortest Path Query Approach for Encrypted Graphs Based on Padding Dictionary Structure
Publication Title: 2023 China Automation Congress (CAC)
Abstract Note: Hybrid intelligence has emerged as an innovative approach that synergistically combines the strengths of human intelligence and artificial intelligence (AI) to address complex problems. In this paradigm, knowledge graphs play a pivotal role by supplying vital background information and contextual understanding to hybrid intelligence systems. However, due to limitations in local storage capacity, managing large-scale graph data often requires outsourcing to cloud servers. Nevertheless, the use of untrusted cloud servers poses a risk of potential user data leaks. To address these concerns, this paper presents an encryption scheme specifically designed to protect graph data, enabling queries involving intermediate nodes in the shortest path between two nodes within the graph. The proposed scheme ensures the privacy and security of outsourced data by employing a novel method that utilizes padding dictionary structure encryption. This method ensures strict limitations on the cloud server's capabilities, restricting it solely to query operations, it effectively prevents any compromise of user data or unauthorized access to sensitive information, users can securely store and process their graph data on servers, significantly reducing the potential risk of data leakage and unauthorized breaches. To validate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed solution, practical experiments were conducted using real-world data.

Author: A. Sikri; G. N; D. K. Doda
Title: Renewal of Cloud-Based Services in Smart Grids
Publication Title: 2023 International Conference on Power Energy, Environment & Intelligent Control (PEEIC)
Abstract Note: Scalable solutions are required to handle fluctuating workloads in modern distribution grids in order to manage the flood of data from many sources, execute dynamic algorithms as needed, and effectively operate sparse actuators. In order to meet these needs, cloud computing technologies have surfaced as a suitable answer, facilitating effective data sharing and interchange. With semantic information integration playing a crucial role, this is especially important for fully exploiting the advantages of cloud computing in enabling sophisticated analytics and mining for smart grids. In order to analyze grid data for power distribution, this essay proposes integrating the semantic web into a cloud-based research platform. The idea recommends using a service restoration technique to reenergize loads after an electrical failure. This presentation is implemented using FIWARE, a platform composed of modular, open-source building pieces designed for future internet services and applications. Moreover, the SARGON ontology-which was created especially for the energy domain-is used here. We test the integration of semantic data into the cloud-based service restoration application using the IEC61850 data model. This integration provides an access to the distribution grid's field devices. The platform's performance test, measured in terms of computing time and network latency, validates the viability of the suggested solution. The results of these experiments provide as a standard against which to measure the performance of smart energy platforms in the future, therefore advancing the field.

Author: A. Jolly; G. Jaglan; V. Pandey; Shashikant; M. Sharma; V. Shrivastava
Title: Leveraging Infrastructure Knowledge Graph for Cloud
Publication Title: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advancement in Electronics & Communication Engineering (AECE)
Abstract Note: Semantic Web and Cloud Computing are two prominent areas within the field of Information Technology that offer distinct solutions to various challenges. The Semantic Web focuses on representing and organizing data in a structured and meaningful way, enabling effective data integration, interoperability, and knowledge discovery. On the other hand, Cloud Computing offers scalable and on-demand access to computing resources, enabling cost-effective storage, processing, and delivery of data and applications. This research article explores the integration of Infrastructure Knowledge Graph in cloud environments. It covers key topics in knowledge graph and cloud technologies, application of semantic web technologies, requirements, performance metrics, and key features of deploying a cloud infrastructure knowledge graph. The paper emphasizes the potential benefits of this integration, including enhanced resource management, improved scalability and performance, streamlined provisioning, data integration, and compliance. By leveraging these technologies, organizations can optimize their cloud infrastructure, drive innovation, and meet the demands of modern computing environment.

Author: A. K. Bishnoi; B. J
Title: Carrying out Encryption and Decryption in a Multi-Tenant Cloud Environment
Publication Title: 2023 6th International Conference on Contemporary Computing and Informatics (IC3I)
Abstract Note: The proliferation of information is increasing on a daily basis; however, it is often accompanied by issues of irrelevance and inadequate security measures. It is imperative to minimize time complexity by furnishing pertinent outcomes to users, thereby enabling them to access cloud services directly in accordance with the pay-per-use policy. The study presents an algorithm that utilizes ontology to execute encryption and decryption of input data within a cloud environment that caters to multiple tenants. The process entails the categorization of categories, attributes, and examples of unstructured language through the creation of an ontology that pertains to a particular field. The ontology has been developed utilizing the Protégé ontology editor and facilitates the retrieval of pertinent information from cloud service providers through a pay-per-use model.

Author: Y. Yao; P. Potikas; K. Potika
Title: Knowledge Graphs for Textbooks: Extraction and Completion Techniques
Publication Title: 2023 IEEE Sixth International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Engineering (AIKE)
Abstract Note: This paper aims to apply knowledge graph construction techniques to textbooks, explicitly focusing on the challenge of the absence of domain-specific schema for each textbook. Various entity and relation extraction models are utilized to capture logical and semantic information related to the textbook’s topic. These models include a Text-Encoding-Initiative (TEI) model to extract hierarchical concepts, spaCy Natural Language Processing (NLP), and Google Cloud Natural Language to extract semantic information from the main textual content. The study includes a case study on a cloud computing textbook, where each approach is evaluated and analyzed. Ultimately, the goal is to create knowledge graphs of textbooks, enabling the completion task of predicting missing entities or relations in a low-dimensional space.

Author: S. Xu; Z. Wu; C. Shi; M. Sun
Title: Cloud Computing Product Service Scheme Recommendation System Based on a Hierarchical Knowledge Graph
Publication Title: IEEE Access
Abstract Note: It is difficult for users to understand the complex cloud product information for product selection. Using this information to recommend satisfactory cloud products is a challenge. Previous studies focused on similar information of users and products while neglecting relevance; therefore, they could not create recommendation approaches that account for functional dependencies among cloud products. To overcome this challenge, this study proposes a cloud product set recommendation model based on a hierarchical knowledge graph (KG) with a pre-post correlation of product functionality. There are two main contributions: First, we constructed a cloud product functionality and performance KG using the dependency information of layers and entities to represent complicated pre-post logical connections. The KG was designed according to the cloud service model. Second, we designed an improved PageRank algorithm to obtain the importance weight for each functionality and performance, which replaces the original average method with the proportion of connection weight. We considered the release time of the functionality, launch time of the product, and last update time of the product as crucial factors in the recommendation score to reflect the importance of the functionality and current development stage of the product. Finally, our method recommended a product set based on the weighted scores from the above results. In addition, we constructed a cloud product functionality dataset containing 339 functionalities. The experimental results show that the proposed method can generate a closely related set of products, leading to improved accuracy and higher satisfaction compared to mainstream methods.
Manual Tags: Cloud computing; Knowledge graphs; Recommender systems; knowledge graph; cloud product functionality dataset; cloud service; PageRank; Product set recommendation; Electronic commerce; Data models; Companies; Industries; Filtering

Author: V. Christou; Y. Wang; Z. Zhao
Title: Towards a Knowledge Graph Enhanced Automation and Collaboration Framework for Digital Twins
Publication Title: 2023 IEEE 19th International Conference on e-Science (e-Science)
Abstract Note: The Digital Twin (DT) provides a digital representation of a physical system and allows users to interactively study the physical processes of a real system via the digital representation in different scenarios in real time. The development of a DT is highly complex; it requires not only expertise from multiple disciplines but also the integration of often heterogeneous software components, e.g., simulations, machine learning, visualization, and user interface components across distributed environments. This poster presents a Knowledge Graph-based ontological framework to boost automation and collaboration during the DT lifecycle stages. We implement our methods in developing a what-if analysis service for a DT of an ecosystem of wetlands and its automated deployment to the Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud.

Author: S. Guiquan; L. Zhenyue; L. Zheheng; Z. Xiaolu
Title: Research on Optimization of Discontinuous Data Path Mining Based on Fuzzy Clustering Algorithm
Publication Title: 2023 International Conference on Networking, Informatics and Computing (ICNETIC)
Abstract Note: Discontinuous data is a kind of large-scale hierarchical data. Generally speaking, this kind of data has time attribute, and it hopes to show some time-varying characteristics on the basis of keeping the hierarchical structure clear. Using path mining to analyze discontinuous data paths in cloud computing environment, we can find the location and data state of discontinuous data paths. Classifying and counting discontinuous data is beneficial to the efficient use of data. In this paper, the optimization of discontinuous data path mining based on fuzzy clustering algorithm is studied. In order to optimize the path mining of discontinuous data based on fuzzy clustering algorithm, this paper extracts the semantic directional features of discontinuous data and quantifies them. On the basis of quantization coding, FCM (fuzzy C means) algorithm is adopted to realize the directional beam clustering of semantic ontology features and improve the path mining algorithm. The research results show that the proposed algorithm is used to optimize the path mining of discontinuous data based on fuzzy clustering algorithm, and the root mean square error of the path mining output is low, which shows that the path mining accuracy is higher than the traditional method and the anti-interference performance is strong.

Author: S. Rai; I. Jain; A. Vij; E. Kaushik
Title: Translational Bioinformatics Ontology In Healthcare With Cloud Computing
Publication Title: 2023 International Conference on Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIET)
Abstract Note: The topic of health informatics known as “translational bioinformatics,” or TBI, is one that is expanding. It gives clinical significance to biological research. The confluence of molecular bioinformatics, biostatistics, statistical genetics, and clinical informatics. We give an overview of bioinformatics, focusing first on preclinical research applications where significant advancements have been made over the past 20 years or so. Next, we look at clinical uses that have generated a lot of interest because of their potential, like clinical genotyping, early detection, predictive disease models, customized treatment, and wellness monitoring. The issues chosen essentially reflect our confidence that this potential will start to be fulfilled soon. The goal of this study is to represent the advancement in biological data and clinical practice. Its benefits are expanded in both biological and healthcare industries. Its emphasis on applying biomedical research in actionable knowledge on humans to improve their health through the use of modern technologies.

Author: Zhang, Y.; Zheng, Y.; Yin, C.; Wang, W.
Title: Research and System Design of Digital Education Mechanism for Vocational Education in Cloud Computing Environment
Publication Title: Proc. Int. Conf. Educ., Knowl. Inf. Manag., ICEKIM
Abstract Note: This study aims to address the core issues of vocational education in the current cloud computing environment, such as the curriculum system lagging behind technological development and the lack of dynamic data support for talent skill assessment. It aims to build a digital education mechanism and system platform based on cloud computing and artificial intelligence technology, and achieve accurate matching of vocational education with industry needs by establishing an education model of "data-driven-intelligent adaptation-dynamic feedback". First, crawler technology is used to integrate 46,000 cloud computing job recruitment data and 32 vocational college teaching data to construct a job capability knowledge graph; secondly, learner portraits are classified based on the K-means clustering algorithm, and a dynamic evaluation system containing 8 dimensions and 64 indicators is established; then a system architecture with three core functions of intelligent course recommendation, virtual training environment, and real-time capability assessment is designed, and an LSTM neural network is introduced for learning behavior prediction. Within a 12-month period of three pilot colleges, the system enables learners to achieve a job adaptation rate of 85.2%, a mean resource allocation delay of 9.24ms, and an employment rate of 92.5%, which verifies the remarkable effect of this mechanism in improving the adaptability of vocational education and provides a replicable technical path for vocational education reform under the background of digital transformation. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author: Xie, X.; Liu, J.; Cao, B.; Peng, Q.; Liu, S.; Kang, G.
Title: Service Recommendation Based on Multi-Level View Contrastive Learning
Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
Abstract Note: In the context of the rapid development of service-oriented computing and cloud computing, selecting the service that meets the user’s needs from an ever-increasing number of Web services is always challenging. Exploiting auxiliary information such as a Knowledge Graph (KG) can significantly improve the effectiveness of service recommendations. However, current KG-based service recommendation methods usually merely integrate the knowledge semantic information into the user-service interaction model, which ignores the importance of global structure and does not fully consider the in-depth learning of individual user preferences. To this end, this paper proposes a Multi-Level View Contrastive Learning for Service Recommendation (MCSR) approach to address the above challenges. In particular, unlike traditional approaches that consider only two views, we consider three views, i.e., the global structure view, the local collaboration view, and the semantic view. Specifically, the user-service graph is regarded as the collaboration view, the service-entity graph as the semantic view, and the user-service-entity graph as the structural view. By applying contrastive learning across these views at different levels, MCSR fully leverages graph features and structural information, integrating auxiliary relational semantics into user-service interaction modeling. Furthermore, recognizing that the influence of auxiliary information on interactions varies between users and services, a meta-network strategy enables adaptive, personalized knowledge transfer across views, significantly improving recommendation accuracy., since the influence of auxiliary information on interactions varies between users and services, a meta-network strategy enables adaptive, personalized knowledge transfer across views, significantly enhancing recommendation accuracy. The experimental results show that MCSR significantly outperforms current state-of-the-art methods, with the positive impact of its key components on the recommended performance verified by ablation experiments. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author: Jakku, P.C.; Chippagiri, S.; Uppalapati, N.R.; Dasi, U.
Title: Multi-Cloud Semantic Orchestration of AI-Driven Pipelines for Privacy-First LLM Inference
Publication Title: Int. Conf. Comput. Technol. Data Commun., ICCTDC
Abstract Note: Because more people need scalable and private Large Language Model (LLM) processing in the cloud, better orchestration methods for using different cloud resources are required. This research proposes a new architecture for handling Multi-Cloud Semantic Orchestration of AI-driven data pipelines to make LLM inference workflows more efficient, secure and in line with company policies. The framework makes it possible to effectively assign tasks and control data with the help of ontology-based knowledge graphs and added metadata by semantic enrichment. Our system uses distributed coordination engines, ensures both differential privacy and secure multiparty computation and selects appropriate models for proper latency, throughput and compliance. Experimental findings from using well-known NLP datasets show that the orchestration strategy proposed here reduces latency by up to 38% and ensures more privacy by 22% than standard single-cloud systems. This research supports better LLM operations (LLMOps) in areas like healthcare and finance, since both need to pay close attention to data protection and privacy laws. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author: Sitanggang, T.W.; Kamar, K.; Priyono, H.; Rahman, A.W.A.; Nusantoro, H.; Sunengsih, M.
Title: Enhancing Educational Data Integrity Using Blockchain and Ontologies
Publication Title: Proceeding - Int. Conf. Creat. Commun. Innov. Technol.: Empower. Transform. MATURE LEADERSH.: Harnessing Technol. Adv. Glob. Sustain., ICCIT
Abstract Note: The growing need for secure and transparent data management in educational institutions has brought attention to Blockchain technology. This study explores the implementation of Blockchain for educational data integrity, focusing on how decentralized ledger technologies (DLTs) and Merkle root methods enhance trust, transparency, and security in academic environments. By integrating an ontology-based framework, this research provides a structured approach to organizing and verifying digital credentials, student records, and institutional data. The ontology aids in reducing conceptual ambiguity and supports interoperability among diverse educational technologies. Through technical analysis of Blockchain components, such as Merkle trees, cryptographic hashes, and block structures, the study demonstrates how Blockchain ensures tamper-proof and verifiable data transactions. Case studies from universities applying Blockchain-Based certification further highlight the feasibility and challenges of adoption, including infrastructure readiness, stakeholder resistance, and integration with legacy systems. The findings suggest that combining Blockchain with emerging technologies like AI and cloud computing can establish a resilient, scalable, and secure educational ecosystem. This paper contributes a theoretical and practical perspective for institutions aiming to modernize academic record keeping while addressing privacy, authenticity, and long-term data sustainability. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author: Yalla, S.T.; Batra, I.; Malik, A.
Title: Security Ontologies in Cloud Computing
Publication Title: Int. Conf. Emerg. Technol., INCET
Abstract Note: Cloud computing (CC) has the potential to augment collaboration, scalability, and accessibility, while providing cost-saving opportunities via enhanced and efficient computing, thus enabling enterprises to maintain focus. Cloud-based security ontologies are organized frameworks that delineate and classify topics pertinent to security in CC settings. They assist in standardizing language and enhance communication, interoperability, and comprehension among diverse stakeholders, including security experts, developers, and organizations. The ontology-based security strategy is one of the security solutions used by relevant parties. Nevertheless, target customers and cloud service providers see it as complex and lacking in security, since the applicable paradigms for various contexts are not clearly defined. Previous research has identified many security ideas that service providers might use, employing several evaluation methodologies. This highlights the growing need for reviewing the literature on Cloud Security Ontology (CSO). This research outlines the current state of the art in cloud computing ontology (CCO) and conducts a comprehensive literature review on the topic. Using the systematic literature review (SLR) approach, we identified 100 papers; 60 were selected based on established criteria, and 25 were assessed to be pertinent to the study. Scholars have shown active interest in four main areas of CC - service description, cloud security (CS), cloud resource management, cloud interoperability, and cloud service discovery - where cloud ontologies have had a significant impact. According to the research, fifteen of the thirty-one methods described in the literature for using ontologies in the cloud domain are still in use in legacy computing settings. The findings reveal several issues with improving company operations in cloud and multi-cloud settings via the use of ontologies. This paper delineates unsolved difficulties and potential future paths for academics in cloud ontology. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author: Xie, X.; Liu, J.; Cao, B.; Zhao, W.; Lin, S.; Shi, M.; Chen, J.
Title: DiffMSR: A Multi-Semantic Graph Diffusion Model for Service Recommendation
Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Services Computing
Abstract Note: With the rapid development of cloud computing and service computing, service recommendation systems play a crucial role in helping users efficiently filter the appropriate services. However, the sparsity of service data and the presence of noise in interactions make it extremely challenging to accurately capture user preferences. Existing service recommendation methods based on Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) primarily rely on ID aggregation, often neglecting the richness of textual semantics and are susceptible to interaction noise, resulting in suboptimal modeling of user-service relationships. Although Large Language Models (LLMs) demonstrate remarkable advantages in capturing textual semantics, current methods struggle to effectively align structural representations with textual representations, limiting improvements in recommendation performance. To address these challenges, we propose an innovative multi-semantic graph diffusion model for service recommendation, DiffMSR, which aims to align textual and structural representations while learning the generation process of interaction graphs in a denoising manner. This approach mitigates data sparsity and effectively reduces noise interference. Specifically, the model leverages LLMs to capture the textual semantic features of service descriptions and integrates them with structured semantic information from knowledge graphs. Through cross-semantic contrastive learning, it achieves heterogeneous semantic alignment. Furthermore, the model introduces a multisemantic diffusion-based generation framework, which iteratively denoises to construct high-quality user-service interaction graphs. This significantly enhances the multi-semantic awareness of user representations, thereby improving recommendation performance. Experiments on public service datasets demonstrate that DiffMSR outperforms existing state-of-the-art baseline methods, achieving improvements of 4.13% and 6.37% in recommendation accuracy and recall, respectively. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author: Aarav Kannan, J.; Amshavalli, R.S.; Venkateswara Reddy, D.; Varma, V.S.V.; Kavitha, G.
Title: A Semantic Driven Framework for Energy Efficient Task Scheduling in Dynamic Cloud Environment
Publication Title: Int. Conf. Sentim. Anal. Deep Learn., ICSADL - Proc.
Abstract Note: The rapid expansion of cloud computing has led to increased energy consumption, raising concerns about its environmental impact. Despite advancements in scheduling algorithms, existing methods face critical challenges, including suboptimal energy efficiency, limited adaptability to dynamic cloud environments, and insufficient context-aware decision-making. Recent techniques, such as Meta Reinforcement Learning, Genetic Algorithms, and Energy-Aware Scheduling, show potential but often struggle with high computational complexity, static resource allocation, or scalability issues. These shortcomings result in inefficient resource utilization, elevated energy usage, and difficulties in meeting Service Level Agreement (SLA) requirements. To address these challenges, this study introduces the Energy Efficient Semantic Scheduling Framework (ESSF), a novel approach combining semantic reasoning and energy profiling to optimize task scheduling in dynamic cloud environments. The framework integrates three key components: (1) Dynamic Energy Profiling (DEP) for real-time energy monitoring, (2) Semantic Resource Matching (SRM) utilizing knowledge graphs for context-aware allocation, and (3) Adaptive Workload Balancing (AWB) to dynamically redistribute tasks for improved resource utilization and energy efficiency. Experiments using the Google Cluster Trace Dataset demonstrate that ESSF reduces energy consumption by up to 25% compared to traditional methods while achieving 90% resource utilization and 97% SLA compliance. These results highlight the potential of the proposed framework to overcome existing limitations, offering a scalable, adaptive, and environmentally sustainable solution for task scheduling in cloud computing. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author: Wong, W.; Alomari, Z.; Shao, Y.; Islam Satti, M.I.
Title: Knowledge Graph to Facilitate Cloud Security Compliance with NIST Cybersecurity Framework
Publication Title: Int. Conf. Comput., Vis. Intell. Technol., ICCVIT - Proc.
Abstract Note: Cybersecurity compliance has become increasingly complex due to evolving threats, overlapping standards, and rapidly changing requirements driven by emerging technologies like artificial intelligence. Organizations face significant challenges in efficiently mapping compliance requirements to specific security controls. This paper addresses this issue within the cloud industry by presenting a systematic approach to deploying a knowledge graph or ontology that maps cloud security controls at the granular implementation level to the NIST Cybersecurity Framework. Unlike previous efforts focused on high-level mappings, this approach enhances compliance efficiency and supports integration with common software languages such as HTTP and Java. The proposed methodology can also be adapted to other compliance standards. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author: Moreschini, S.; Albano, M.; Hästbacka, D.
Title: Best Practices for Resource Provisioning Declaration Within the Cognitive Cloud Continuum
Publication Title: Proc. Euromicro Conf. Softw. Eng. Adv. Appl., EUROMICRO-SEAA
Abstract Note: The evolution of cloud computing, driven by ad-vances in mobile, edge technologies, and AI, has led to the development of the Cognitive Cloud Continuum (COCLCON). However, this paradigm introduces new challenges in managing and optimizing computing resources across a heterogeneous environment. This paper explores best practices for declaring resources within COCLCON, with a focus on efficient resource allocation and transparently declaring available resources by de-vices. In this study, we undertook a non-holistic literature review to identify current technologies used to specify requirements and to determine current gaps in best practices. The main outcome of our work is a proposed schema for Resource Provisioning Declaration, which will allow for increased knowledge related to the available devices and resources within the COCLCON. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author: Cecil, R.R.; Miranda, J.L.; Nagy, M.; Silveira, M.; Zanin, M.
Title: Advanced Methodologies and Technologies for Innovative Information Systems
Publication Title: Proc. - IEEE Int. Conf. Bioinform. Biomed., BIBM
Abstract Note: Nowadays, Information Systems (IS) in healthcare systems are being successively updated, either incorporating advanced Optimization tools combined with Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Large Language Models (LLM), or using innovative computing features for storage, processing, security, privacy, and friendly interface. Large efforts are required to design, validate and implement such developments, diverse communities in multiple scientific domains are involved, and new approaches are key to cope with the transdisciplinary gaps. In this paper we outline and discuss the relevant technologies and methodologies for IS within the context of health emergencies. Advanced and innovative approaches are being applied within the Health Informatics area, and we address a set of key technologies (e.g., Cloud Computing, AI-based platforms, Neural Networks) and methodologies (e.g., Knowledge Graphs, advanced Optimization, Multi-Criteria Decision Making) that are being relevant within the Health Emergency Responses (HER) framework, and also for the health informatics communities. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author: Chen, Z.; Zhao, Y.; Teng, F.; Hu, J.; Tian, B.; Zhang, H.
Title: Dynamic Searchable Symmetric Encrypted Knowledge Graph
Publication Title: Int. Conf. Commun. Softw. Networks, ICCSN
Abstract Note: With the rapid development of knowledge graphs and cloud computing, most people choose to store knowledge graphs on commercial cloud platforms. However, since cloud platforms are not completely trustworthy, this exposes graph data to security risks. Therefore, protecting knowledge graph data stored on third-party cloud platforms is essential. Based on these considerations, we propose a Dynamic Searchable Symmetric Encryption-based Knowledge Graph scheme (DSSE-KG). DSSE-KG aims to address the privacy and security risks associated with storing knowledge graph data on cloud servers. Compared to existing schemes, DSSE-KG not only ensures the data security of knowledge graphs but also provides multi-hop relationship retrieval and dynamic update capabilities. Performance tests on multiple publicly available real-world datasets demonstrate that the DSSE-KG scheme achieves a good balance between security, functionality, and efficiency for knowledge graphs. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
